BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are prone to triggering in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular above the tree line, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can be released easily and reach medium size. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be strong in some cases. As a consequence of new snow and wind from northerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed. More recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of rising temperatures the snowpack will settle during the next few days. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of wet loose snow avalanches being released will increase for a while in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the moderate to strong northerly wind the prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northerly directions, further wind slabs will form in high Alpine regions. The wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on very steep grassy slopes moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. The avalanche prone locations for wet avalanches are to be found in particular below approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: More recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs formed since Wednesday above approximately 2100 m.
Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2500 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Meticulous route selection is important. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended. The presence of numerous potentially unstable frames is noted, attention to the areas below.
At high altitude individual medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate northerly wind.
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation a very high danger of moist snow slides will prevail. This applies on extreme sunny slopes, and in steep rocky terrain below approximately 2700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual, in particular above approximately 2200 m.
40 to 70 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2200 m
The strong wind has transported the new snow.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Continuous warming: These conditions will foster a gradual change towards better conditions in particular at intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Until Saturday the wind will be strong to storm force at times over a wide area. The wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on wind-loaded slopes of all aspects above approximately 2200 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m.
The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. In some regions up to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. The sleet gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind has transported the fresh and old snow. The wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. This applies in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong northerly wind, further wind slabs will form on Thursday in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but can be released easily especially at their margins.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase a little in particular on very steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, especially in the north. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, wind slabs will form. These are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of wet loose snow avalanches being released will increase for a while in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The Avalanche Warning Service currently has only a small amount of information that has been collected in the field, so that the avalanche danger should be investigated especially thoroughly in the relevant locality.
The fresh snow as well as the small wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs are lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Currently there are quite favourable conditions generally. The old snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in the vicinity of peaks and on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The older wind slabs are easy for the trained eye to recognise and can only be released in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed in the last three days above approximately 2200 m.
Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases. This applies in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2500 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
At elevated altitudes individual small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate northerly wind.
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation a very high danger of moist snow slides will prevail. This applies on extreme sunny slopes, and in steep rocky terrain below approximately 2700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2200 m
The strong wind has transported the new snow.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Continuous warming: These conditions will foster a gradual change towards better conditions in particular at intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls. In particular on very steep sunny slopes mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released in some cases even by a single winter sport participant. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on very steep grassy slopes moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. The avalanche prone locations for wet avalanches are to be found in particular below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at low and intermediate altitudes. At low altitude only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. On Friday the wind slabs have increased in size additionally. Mostly avalanches are small but can be released easily even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The small wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 1800 m and on south and southwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A little new snow above approximately 1200 m. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northeasterly wind, small wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very early morning: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Isolated small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very early morning: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. In particular on very steep sunny slopes and at higher altitudes individual small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines as well as above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
